revised_title: Adaptation to Structurally Different Environments: Bacteria and Habitat Specialization
tldr: This study investigates how bacteria adapt to different environments and if inhabiting structurally different environments promotes the evolution of distinct adaptations. Two experimental habitats were arranged: a homogeneous one with free-floating cells and a structured one with cells forming layers on a solid medium. The results showed that bacteria adapted not only to the habitat structure but also to nutritional conditions. Evolution in a non-homogeneous environment produced a greater variety of adaptations, suggesting that specialization may result in fitness trade-offs.
